title: Welcome
text: Welcome to the BST623 R Programming resource page! This site provides a collection of functions commonly used in the BST623 class, making it easier for you to access and utilize R programming tools in your coursework. Whether you’re a seasoned programmer or new to R, this page is designed to provide a comprehensive and user-friendly experience. Happy coding!

title: About
text: BST623 Software Tools for Manuscript Development and Reproducible Research is a course at the University of Miami, offered by the Biostatistics program. This class is taught by professor, Dr. Raymond Balise. The course focus on the use of software tools for creating professional-quality manuscripts and conducting reproducible research. Whether you’re an experienced researcher or just starting out, BST 623 will provide valuable skills and knowledge to use R for your research.

title: BST623 functions
text:
The Library Function
The library function is used in R to load packages from installed libraries into the active R session. It helps to prevent a user from needing to type multiple lines of code for a single package. This can be useful for saving time when loading multiple packages into the active R session.

What Package Does It Contain?
The library function contains packages found in the default libraries of R and user-installed packages. Packages can be specified as either a full name or partial names if the user cannot remember the full name.

title: BST623 functions
text:
Function name: conflicted_prefer()


Notes:


[conflicted::conflicted_prefer()]
.small[ [[conflicted_prefer]("*function*", "*winning package*", quiet = TRUE)]] + The conflicted packages complains when the same function name is used in multiple packages. + Use conflicted_prefer() to specify which version should be used by default.

conflict_prefer("filter", "dplyr", quiet = TRUE)


You can overwrite this default with package::function().

title: BST623 functions
text:
Function name: %>%


Notes:


[%>%]
[ \(thing_1\) [%>%]
\(thing_2\)] + The symbol [%>%] is called a pipe. When describing a workflow, it is spoken as “then”. + It sends the output from \(thing_1\) to the first argument of \(thing_2\).

nrow(medicaldata::covid_testing) %>% 
  scales::comma() %>% 
  print()


Many functions can be connected in a pipeline.
Start code after a pipe on a new line.
Indent all lines of code two spaces after the first pipe.

Source Function

1. Brief Description
The source() function is used in R in order to read and evaluate scripture in the R language. The script can be either a pre-existing script or a script written in R. The source function enables the user to execute scripts written in R within the existing R environment, allowing them to use existing features and variables.


2. What Package Contains It
source() is part of the base R language, not a package.


3. When to Use it

This command allows you to set the default behavior for code chunks when knitting
For example, this specifies that you want to always show code but never run it

This command belongs in the “setup” chunk at the top of an R Markdown script.

title: BST623 functions
text:
Function name: nrow()


Notes:


[nrow()]
[[nrow](*dataset*)] + [nrow()] reports the number of rows/records in a dataset (or matrix).

nrow(mtcars)

[1] 32



You will likely use this with [scales::comma()] to include the number of observations in a dataset as part of a report.


scales::comma(
  nrow(medicaldata::covid_testing)
)

[1] "15,524"

title: BST623 functions
text:
Function name: cat()


Notes:


[cat()]
[[cat](*things*)] .pull-left-60[ + [cat()] is simpler version of the [paste()] function. + It does not print the vector position, like [1]. + It does not prints a slash before quotes. + The [glue::glue()] is an excellent alternative.] .pull-right-36[

cat("The cyberman", "cried.")

The cyberman cried.

cat('The cyberman said "error."')

The cyberman said "error."

words <- "Hi Mom"
cat("Ray said ", '"', words, '".')

Ray said  " Hi Mom ".


]

NA

title: BST623 functions
text:
Function name: <-


Notes:


[<-]
[[*thingy* <- *something*]] + You use [<-] to assign an object (e.g., thingy) a value (e.g., something). + The [<-] operator is pronounced “gets.” + In other languages this would be an =.

everything <- 42


Use an [=], not [<-] , to assign values to an argument in a function call.
You can also use [->] (e.g., something [->] thingy) but it violates all style guides.


NA

title: BST623 functions
text:
Function name: R.Version()


Notes:


[R.Version()]
[[R.Version]()] + [R.Version()] returns a list of details about the version of that is currently running.

R.Version()

[[R.version.string]] + [R.version.string] is an easier to work with description of your version of R:

R.version.string


This is useful for extracting the version of R for publications: stringr::word(R.version.string, 1, 3)

title: BST623 functions
text:
Function name: options()


Notes:


[options()]
.small[ [[options](*option* = *value*)]] + The [options()] function sets the global behavior used by R, including how numbers are printed/formatted.
+ Some packages allow you to set default behavior. + For example, you can turn off messages about how [summarise()] function behaves in [dplyr] with this option:

options(dplyr.summarise.inform=FALSE)




Options Function
The options function is a powerful utility provided in R to help configure the environment of your R session. It allows users to customize various settings, from printing to memory limits.
This function can be found in the base package.
The options function is useful when you need to adjust the environment for specific tasks, for example, setting a specific seed for random number generation or adjust whether warnings will be printed or not.
An example of how to use the options function would be to set a seed before running your

Function name: class()


Notes:
Empty


Class Function
Class functions are a set of methods in R, the language of statistical computing, to combine data types into a single object. It is part of the S3 generic system in R and allows the users to use methods to modify or create objects.
Class functions are part of the stats package in R and can help users create simple as well as more sophisticated objects. The stats package also includes basic tools for projecting and analyzing data.
When it comes to using class functions, there are different cases that may require different levels of complexity. For example

The min function returns the minimum element from a given set or input. This is typically an array or vector. The min function scans through the set of values and finds the smallest number.

Function name: fct_recode()


Notes:
Empty


fct_recode

1. Brief Description
The fct_recode function is an R command used to convert one factor into another. This is accomplished by assigning values of one factor to all possible values of another factor. This can be useful, for example, when dealing with qualitative data containing two-level factors, especially if the levels are more meaningful than their numeric equivalents.


2. What Package Contains it?
The fct_recode function is part of the forcats package. This package

title: BST623 functions
text:
Function name: group_by()


Notes:


[group_by()] \(_1\)
[[group_by](tableName, groupingVariable)] Before dplyr 1.1 to get groups you would tag the dataset as having a grouping variable:

laryngectomy %>%
  select(gender, length_fu) %>% 
  `group_by(gender)` # marks the grouping variable







Group_By Function

1. Brief Description
The group_by function is a versatile and powerful function in R that allows users to assign observations into groups and apply analysis or transformations within these groups.


2. What Package Does It Belong To
The group_by function is retrieved from the dplyr package.


3. When To Use It
This function should be used when you want to apply analysis or transformations to single or multiple groups of similar observations.

Function name: pivot_wider()


Notes:


[pivot_wider()] is a thing.

There is function called pivot_wider() that will take long data and make it wider.
I rarely use it. Know it exists.




The pivot_wider() Function
The pivot_wider function is a useful tool for transforming tidy data into a wider format. It is an improved version of the spread() operation from the tidyr package and expands to more than two columns from the input data.
The pivot_wider() function is a part of the tidyr package version 1.0.0 and above.
The pivot_wider() function should be used to transform a dataset with a one-column key into a wider format, where the rows and column names refer to the

select(data_frame, column_

title: BST623 functions
text:
Function name: typeof()


Notes:


[typeof()]
.small[ [[typeof](*vector*)] [[typeof](*dataset$variable*)] + The “type” of an object helps determine what behaviors an object can do.
+ You can not take the mean of a character variable. + These are the typical types that are used in datasets: .pull-left[ + int = “integer” for numbers without decimals + dbl = “double” for numbers with decimals + lgl = “logical” for true/false + date = “date”] .pull-right[ + chr = “character” for character string + fct = “factor” for categories that are not ordered + ord = “ordered” for ordered categories]

typeof(pi)
typeof(R.version$nickname)


Other “types” are used to categorize functions and other complex objects.
R also uses [mode()] to describe type. It groups “integer” and “double” as “numeric”. ]




typeof function
The typeof function is a basic R function that determines the type of object passed to it.
The typeof function belongs to the base package of R.
The typeof function should be used when you need to determine the class of an object. This is important to know because each class of object has specific methods and functions that can be used on them.
An example of how to use the typeof function in R is as follows:
```R # Determine the type of the object ‘x’

title: BST623 functions
text:
Function name: count()


Notes:


[count()]
[[count](table, variables)] dplyr can do fancy summary statistics but [count()] is quick, easy and useful for frequency counts: .pull-left-60[

laryngectomy %>%
  mutate(isMale = 2 - gender ) %>%
  mutate(sex = as.character(isMale)) %>%
  mutate(sex = fct_recode(sex, 
                          "Female" = "0", 
                          "Male" = "1")) %>% 
  mutate(stage = fct_recode(as.character(int_stg), 
                          "T1" = "1", 
                          "T2" = "2",
                          "T3" = "3",
                          "T4" = "4",
                          "Unknown" = "5")) %>% 
  `count(sex, stage)` %>% 
  arrange(sex, stage)  # this just sorts by sex then stage

] .pull-right-36[



]



The count Function
The count function is a useful tool for summarizing data in R. It allows you to quickly count the number of occurrences of an item or items in a vector. It is particularly helpful when working with categorical data.
The count function is contained in the dplyr package. It is important to ensure that the dplyr package is loaded before you try to use the count function.
It is best to use the count function when you have categorical data or data that can be easily divided into categories and you want to quickly

Kable Function
Kable is a function that creates a data frame object in the R programming language. It creates the object and enables users to display the data frame in a nice looking table in the RStudio console or a Jupyter Notebook.
The kable function is contained in the knitr package. This package provides a collection of functions that can be used to produce beautiful tables in both html and other formats.

title: BST623 functions
text:
The Library Function
The library function is used in R to load packages from installed libraries into the active R session. It helps to prevent a user from needing to type multiple lines of code for a single package. This can be useful for saving time when loading multiple packages into the active R session.

What Package Does It Contain?
The library function contains packages found in the default libraries of R and user-installed packages. Packages can be specified as either a full name or partial names if the user cannot remember the full name.

conflict_prefer("filter", "dplyr", quiet = TRUE)

nrow(medicaldata::covid_testing) %>%

[[cat](*things*)] .pull-left-60[ + [cat()] is simpler version of the [paste()] function. + It does not print the vector position, like [1]. + It does not prints a slash before quotes. + The [glue::glue()] is an excellent alternative.] .pull-right-36[

cat("The cyberman", "cried.")

The cyberman cried.

cat('The cyberman said "error."')

The cyberman said "error."

[<-]
[[*thingy* <- *something*]] + You use [<-] to assign an object (e.g., thingy) a value (e.g., something). + The [<-] operator is pronounced “gets.” + In other languages this would be an =.

everything <- 42


Use an [=], not [<-] , to assign values to an argument in a function call.
You can also use [->] (e.g., something [->] thingy) but it violates all style guides.

options(dplyr.summarise.inform=FALSE)

Class Function
Class functions are a set of methods in R, the language of statistical computing, to combine data types into a single object. It is part of the S3 generic system in R and allows the users to use methods to modify or create objects.
Class functions are part of the stats package in R and can help users create simple as well as more sophisticated objects. The stats package also includes basic tools for projecting and analyzing data.
When it comes to using class functions, there are different cases that may require different levels of complexity. For example

Many functions can be connected in a pipeline.
Start code after a pipe on a new line.
Indent all lines of code two spaces after the first pipe.

Brief Description
The tidymodels_prefer() function is a tool for quickly loading tidymodels packages and making them available in an R session. It is included as part of the tidymodels suite, which includes a variety of tools for building statistical models and machine learning models in R.

title: BST623 functions

Function name: source()


Notes:
Empty


Source Function

1. Brief Description
The source() function is used in R in order to read and evaluate scripture in the R language. The script can be either a pre-existing script or a script written in R. The source function enables the user to execute scripts written in R within the existing R environment, allowing them to use existing features and variables.


2. What Package Contains It
source() is part of the base R language, not a package.


3. When to Use it
The `source()

title: BST623 functions
text:
Pull Function

Brief Description
The pull() function is a convenience function for quickly extracting values out of a list-like object. It works similarly to [, but is especially useful for extracting values by name.


What Package Contains It
The pull() function is in the dplyr package.


When to Use It
This is a great function for quickly extracting values from lists, data frames, and tibbles.


An Example of How to Use It in R

Brief Description
The use_tile_view function is an interactive map visualization tool created by Rstudio’s GGPlot2 package in R. It allows a user to visualize geographic data in an easy to read visual format.

title: BST623 functions
text:
1. Brief Description
The build_pdf() function allows users to create a PDF document from an R Markdown file. This makes it possible to easily produce documents when using R Markdown that can be shared and viewed outside of R Studio.

title: BST623 functions
text:
2. What Package Contains it
The build_pdf() function is part of the rmarkdown package. This package can be installed using the install.packages() function or by searching for it through the R Studio built-in package

[[rm](*things*)] + The [rm()] function removes an object from R’s working memory.

life_the_universe_and_everything <- 42
rm(life_the_universe_and_everything)
